Situation1: They have argued repeatedly this week about finances.
Situation2: They notice swimmers occasionally entering the shallow area without supervision.
Story:
I stand at my post, scanning the pool, but my mind keeps drifting back to the argument I had with Emily this morning. We’ve been fighting all week about money—she wants us to start saving for a trip, but I barely make enough as a lifeguard to cover my share of the rent. I know she expects me to talk things through, to fix this tension between us, but every time I try, I just end up making it worse.

A group of kids giggles as they slip into the shallow end, no adult in sight. I’m supposed to be strict about the rules—no unsupervised swimmers, ever. My supervisor made it clear: one slip-up, and I’m out. But my phone buzzes in my pocket. It’s Emily, probably wanting to talk, to resolve things before her shift starts. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me—her need for reassurance, my duty to keep these kids safe. My heart pounds as I look from the phone to the pool, torn between the person I love and the job I can’t afford to lose.
